span: Okay. So this...um...Panel A has...a red cone.

span: So what is the difference?

span: (5.0) The purple [blue] cone...purple [blue]...cone.

span: Okay, so they both have two purple [blue] cones, but B doesn't have two purple [blue] cones, so that can't be associated.

span: Okay, A has two green. Panel B has two green, panel E has three. So, it can't be because of the green cone.
summary: Dismisses green-cone count rule

span: Okay, so I think I'm noticing that it has something to do with the little purple [blue] cone because C,  D and F don't have little purple [blue] cones.

span: They all have...oh, wait...okay. So, most of them have little green cones.

span: All three of the lit up panels have green cones but so does F and C– no just F.

span: things. So, I think it has to do with the little purple [blue] cone.

span: But E also does and that's not lit up.

span: But it doesn't have two. It only has one.

span: I'm pretty sure they have to have two purple [blue] cones that are lying on their side.

span: All right. Panel A, panel C, panel F are lit up.

span: So that can't be it.

span: Like C doesn't have it. D doesn't have it. And F doesn't have it. They have a red pointing up in F, but it's covered by the green and I won't count that... This one also has it, but it’s a red on top so I'm not counting that.
